nl.fw.yapool

Class BoundPool<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.fw.yapool.Pool<T>
      • nl.fw.yapool.BoundPool<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IPool<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    PrunedPool

    public class BoundPool<T>
extends Pool<T>
    A LIFO pool that respects a minimum and maximum size. This pool must be open()ed before it can be used. The pool keeps track of what resources are part of the pool and provides methods for removing idle resources or evicting resources that are leased. The pool can be flushed which removes all idle resources and evicts all leased resources.
    Author:
    Fred

      • create

        protected T create(boolean inLeasedState,
       boolean rethrowRuntimeException)
        Creates a resource (in a synchronized manner if isSyncCreation() is true), but only if pool is not full.
        Parameters:
        inLeasedState - if true, registers the created resource as leased
        rethrowRuntimeException - if true, any factory-create RuntimeExcepions are re-thrown
        Returns:
        null or a new (leased) resource.

      • acquire

        public T acquire(long acquireTimeOutMs)
        Acquires a resource in the following manner:
        - if pool size is below the minimum, try to create a resource (catch factory-create RuntimeException).
        - try to acquire an idle resource if one is available at present
        - if pool size is below the maximum, try to create a resource (catch factory-create RuntimeException)
        - wait for an idle resource to become available
        - if pool size is below the maximum, try to create a resource (throw factory-create RuntimeException)
        - throw a NoSuchElementException when no resource was acquired.
        This procedure will let the caller wait when resources can temporarily not be created (e.g. connection to database is lost for a small period). At the same time, if resources can be created again within the acquire-time, the caller will not notice that the resources were unavailable for a small period.
        Specified by:
        acquire in interface IPool<T>
        Overrides:
        acquire in class Pool<T>
        Parameters:
        acquireTimeOutMs - acquire time in milliseconds. Any value smaller than 1 means "do not wait at all".

      • acquireIdle

        protected T acquireIdle(long acquireTimeOutMs)
        Overrides:
        acquireIdle in class Pool<T>
        Parameters:
        acquireTimeOutMs - If the time is less than or equal to zero, the method will not wait at all.
        Returns:
        the idle resource from the pool, or null if none could be acquired

      • release

        public T release(T t)
        Puts the resource back in the pool so that it can be re-used. If the resource was evicted or not leased (i.e. a foreign resource), the resource will be destroyed (and not put back into the pool).
        Specified by:
        release in interface IPool<T>
        Overrides:
        release in class Pool<T>
        Parameters:
        t - The leased resource to put back into the pool.
        Returns:
        null if the resource was not put back in the pool.

      • removeIdle

        protected T removeIdle(boolean fireIdledEvent)
        Removes the last/longest waiting resource in the idle-queue and destroys it, if any.
        Returns:
        the resource removed from the idle-queue or null.

      • removeIdle

        protected T removeIdle(T t,
           boolean fireIdledEvent)
        Tries to remove the given resource from the idle-queue. On success, destroys the resource.
        Parameters:
        t - the resource to remove from the idle-queue. If null, last resource in queue is removed (which is longest in the idle-queue).
        Returns:
        null if the resource could not be removed from the idle-queue, else the given resource.

      • evictLeased

        public boolean evictLeased(T t,
                  boolean destroy)
        Evicts the leased resource from the pool. Does not fire an PoolEvent.LEASE_EXPIRED event.
        Parameters:
        destroy - if true, the evicted resource is destroyed. If false, make sure to destroy/close the resource yourself when appropriate. Note that an evicted resource that is (eventually) released to the pool, is always detroyed by the pool (and not put back into the pool).
        t - The leased resource to evict.
        Returns:
        true if the resource was found in the leased resources list and evicted.

      • evictIdle

        public boolean evictIdle(T t)
        Evicts the idle resource from the pool and destroys it. Does not fire an PoolEvent.IDLE_EXPIRED event.
        Parameters:
        t - The idle resource to evict.
        Returns:
        true if the resource was found in the idle resources list and evicted.

      • removeLeased

        protected T removeLeased(T t,
             boolean destroyEvicted,
             boolean fireLeaseExpiredEvent)
        Removes a leased resource from the pool.
        Parameters:
        t - The leased resource to remove
        destroyEvicted - If true, the removed resource is also destroyed.
        fireLeaseExpiredEvent - If true, a PoolEvent.LEASE_EXPIRED is fired.
        Returns:
        null if the leased resource could not be removed from the pool, else t.

      • destroy

        protected void destroy(T t)
        Calls the factory to destroy the resource and fires a destroy-event. Method is called when resource is removed from pool.

      • flush

        public Set<T> flush()
        Removes all idle and leased resources from the pool. Idle resources are destroyed, leased resource that are evicted are not destroyed (but will be when they are released to the pool).
        Returns:
        all resources removed from the pool.
